description:
Really good food, amazing taste, great service and something different than the usual fare!

Came here on a Tuesday For the Kati Roll special night - different and delicious!   Followed up with a traditional favorite of Lamb Biryani, and then the unusual - Pork Vindaloo!  The Vindaloo meat was sooooo tender and delicious!  Saved room for dessert (well, not really, we stuffed it in as portions on dinner were very good!). Strawberry Kulfi with basil seeds and vermicelli, and a roasted rice pudding with Carmel nut brittle.  yummy!!!!

Will be back again!  Loved finding choices you wouldn't find elsewhere!  Come try it!!

Great service as well!  It was a bit quiet, but staff was very friendly and attentive!!
author: Todd M.

description:
As Yelpers, we tend to cherry-pick our restaurant experiences to curate the best possible meals. But we forget that long before the Internet, people found the best meals by word-of-mouth. Ritu, on the recommendation of my cousins, happened to serve up one of those delightful dinners.

We hopped in on a Wednesday evening and it was almost entirely empty. True to the ultra-trendy feel of San Franciscan restaurants, it features glowy hanging lamp orbs, lots of light wood accents, and an open kitchen where you can watch the chefs cook up some delights. Opting to have a good conversation instead, we sat down at one of the three-person tables toward the front.

Within minutes of sitting down, someone came by to take our order. We went with three crowd favorites: chicken tikka masala with naan, lamb biryani, and chicken biryani. Everything was cooked to order and came out very quickly, an excellent selling point for diners who want a fast meal.

Although it wasn't my dish, I sampled a bit of the chicken tikka masala off of my cousin's plate. Wow, the poultry was so tender that I barely had to chew before it melted in my mouth. It was also so creamy that it brought forth visions of cats lapping up cream from saucers. I'd definitely recommend this as an intro to Indian cuisine for not-so-adventurous eaters.

Our biryanis were served with tiny bowls of chaat with chickpeas that really cut through the spice profile of the rice. I was also really pleased with the color of the rice, which came a gorgeous yellow that looked as fragrant and delicate as it was. I could not finish that heaping plate in one sitting, but I found myself at a point where I just wanted to keep eating the chunks of lamb. Like the chicken, it was supremely tender, and spiced very well. Someone offered up a takeout box for leftovers, and I can confirm that it tastes almost as magical reheated.
author: Gwen W.

description:
Trendy and open inside with some nice, modern decor. 

Food has some items with a twist (beet chaat, artichoke pakora) but also if you're craving your uz stuff like channa masala they have that too. 

The food is all really, really solid. I tried a bunch of their stuff and no complaints at all about anything. 

Prices are p reasonable too for SF (remember its a nicer spot). 

Also, portions are LARGE. The side of channa masala for $6 is the size of entrees at many places.
author: Aria S.

description:
I enjoyed the many dishes that were served that night. Highlights were the kale chaat - crispy and would order again, fish with coconut curry - fish was cooked perfectly. We didn't try two of the second courses, but were quite full and needed to save room for desserts. I like the roasted rice pudding with raisins and nut brittle. Something familiar, but would love this flavor in an ice cream form!  The pistachio pot de creme was good. Love the flavor as well.

The chef/owner - who does EVERYTHING including handling the bathroom not flushing, props to you. Also, props to the staffs - kitchen, waiters and Ben/ team (sorry, I can't remember names at this very moment).
author: Mandy D.

description:
I must've caught them at a great time, not too busy.
I walked in and the vibe was peaceful with smooth  Punjab music in the back ground what I expected.

I was bit confused seeing how I have never ordered Indian food before and it took a good 15 minutes just looking at the menu; what I thought my catch my eye. Chef Rupam Bhangat brought me to ease when he told me he had no problem putting together a customized dish for me. Explaining he comes across these situations like this all the time. 

I order the steam fish over a cooked tomato sauce with cilantro and other spices gluten free that blended together quite evenly along side with brown rice with split peas. Out of this world! The chef does not hold back on giving you big chunks of fish in your dish well worth it. $17


Strawberry honey lime and mint soda in a jar was refreshing, but remember to stir it or you will only be tasting seltzer and a hint of strawberry.  "Stir stir stir"  to get the flavor your hoping to have. 


Cabernet$12

Pistachio pot de Creme is my absolute favorite thing out of everything here. It's a twist on pudding and creme brûlée, except it's cold. At first I didn't  get why he put sea salt in the whip cream. Eventually I caught in after to scoops and discovered he was trying to balance out sweetness mixed with the pistachio, and it turned out really nice. 

Pleasant experience, and smiling face staff.
author: Elijajuan F.

description:
We went there for a Yelp Elite event and there was not one thing I tried I didn't like. Everything was just so amazing and perfectly cooked, with lots of flavors and a beautiful presentation! I loved everything about Ritu - from the restaurant itself, to the food (of course) to the staff. Such amazing people working there! :)
For your main dish, I would say the curry is pretty amazing as well as the rice with chicken and the deep fried kale (yep!) - for dessert I would recommend their pistachio mousse - incredible. Love this place!
author: Daffny V.

description:
Walked in on a Sunday afternoon while visiting SanFran. Mom wanted some soulful Indian food, so we chose Ritu Indian Soul Food.
Started with:

Avocado and sprouts bhel:  just amazing! The avocado slices and sprouts blend so well with the classic bhel! Just explosions of flavors in your mouth! This dish is genius. Must try!

Lamb T Bone steak: Beautifully done! It was well marinated and presented well! This is a tricky one , lamb meat is very risky and yet they had nailed it. 


Biryani: coming from Hyderabad I did not quite understand the taste signature, but it wasn't bad at all. The rice was soft as rose petal and flavors delicate and blends well. Meat is tender AF as well. Well done. 

I hope they bring name to the ancient Indian cuisine in the land that hasn't quite yet unlocked their taste buds to the fullest potential.
author: Pavithran C.

description:
This is nothing like your regular indian restaurant, the menu items have a nice twist to them which sounded good in concept and theory but implementation didn't live up to the expectations. For ex, one of their bread options was the broccoli cheese paratha, where the bread wasn't stuffed with indian cottage cheese (paneer) but some sort of swiss cheese and tasted average. We ordered the malai kofta for the main entree and it was stuffed with green peas, something I hadn't seen anywhere else but I wasn't too impressed with the pairing.

The place was quite empty on a saturday night and the service was slow.  They had an old menu posted on their website. The handle on the entry door to the restaurant was broken. Portion sizes are small, $8 for an average paratha seemed steep. I don't think we are returning.
author: Preeti R.

description:
Comfy atmosphere and homey Indian food right here! 

This restaurant is only a couple blocks from 24th St. Mission BART which makes it super accessible if you're trying to get some Indian comfort food. I love that mirrors in the restaurant make it look more open yet still intimate from the warm orange colors and viewable kitchen space. It's super nice you can see the chefs cooking from the tables. 

Some of their best dishes for me was their Crispy Kale Chaat and Steamed Fish with Curry. The Crispy Kale Chaat was super crispy, was nicely seasoned, and had a slightly nutty flavor that I really liked to start off my meal. The Steamed Fish was cooked super well. It was very flaky. I thought it could use a touch more salt, but the dish was great. The curry was nice and buttery which made it perfect for dipping into naan!

Surprisingly, I loved the desserts here. I had the Pistachio Pot de Creme and Rice Pudding. Both desserts weren't overly sweet but still decadent enough to satisfy at the end of the meal! Honestly even if I wasn't in the mood for Indian food, I would get a carnitas burrito from El Faro and still come all the way here just for some awesome desserts. Definitely don't skip out on it if you plan to check it out!
author: Clarissa C.

description:
I really love the ambiance of the restaurant. The decor feels very warm and inviting. The lighting makes me feel that we were in Christmas time.

I love the Dahi Puri, the crispy and tangy combo was really delicious. The crispy kale chaat was also very creative and delicious, basically cleaned the bowl by myself. Another favorite is the veggie korma, which is surprising to me since I love meat. But the curry sauce of the korma was very tasty, I cleaned this bowl again (notice a pattern here?).

The desserts were also amazing! I had a low expectation because the owner said they're not dessert chefs. However, they're really tasty and unique. I'd definitely come back for the pistachio pot de creme.

The Almanac beer that accompanied the meal was delicious too, such a good addition to the already delicious meal.
author: Novalina N.

description: We ordered the ribs, lamb korma, paneer curry, garlic naan, eggplant side dish, and saffron rice. The eggplant is actually my favorite - they should make it a main dish  so good with rice
author: Weich Y.

description: This place has a limited menu. I tried the side of dal makhani and cheese chilly naan. The dal was good and as the name says warmed my soul. The portion size of a side is adequate for one person. My friend tried the chicken biryani and honestly it wasn't great! They had some interesting drinks and I was tempted to try the masala coke which was a little overpriced and not great. Overall wasn't a bad experience and I would go there again!
author: Disha A.

description:
This is a pretty stylish Indian restaurant that doesn't call undue attention to itself like the more slickly presented Amber India (review: http://bit.ly/2C5X15d) and August 1 Five (review: http://bit.ly/2C6NI52). That may be due to its genesis from a popular albeit modest food truck at Off the Grid to a brick-and-mortar space that housed the late, lamented Local Mission Eatery on 24th Street,  a more ambitious venture that closed a couple of Decembers ago. Owner Rupam Bhagat has taken advantage of Local's modern decor and wisely kept his menu simple and straightforward. It also appears to have a decidedly Southern twang. Not southern like Kerala, I mean Deep South like something off the interstate in Georgia. For instance, main plates include Tandoori Fried Chicken and Seafood Stew.

Traditionalists need not worry as more recognizably South Asian fare like Paneer Kofta, Vegetable Korma, and Samosas were present and accounted for (photo: http://bit.ly/2CgLZJl). Being somewhat restrictive in my nutritional intake, I zeroed in on the mysterious $13 Vegetarian Bowl of the Day in the Biryani section, so I interrogated the server about it. He simply described it as delicious if you don't eat meat. Sold. I'm not a strict vegetarian but I play one on TV. Wait, wasn't that a commercial for Vicks Formula 44? Anyhow, I've been having more and more veggie and vegan meals just to even my system out. Turned out the server was right, and I have a feeling it was Rupam because he spoke of the food so meticulously and discouraged me from ordering any side dishes as the portion was generous.

Well OK then. He was right, and it was full of goodness starting with the fresh okra, carrots, green beans, and peas down to the seared onion strings, julienned cilantro, and saffron-infused jasmine rice (photo: http://bit.ly/2pQd9lA). It was a Bollywood-style Chipotle veggie burrito bowl amped up with South Asian flair. I did have the temerity to order the $3 side of Paneer cheese, which came cubed and sauced (photo: http://bit.ly/2DtRYrm). It had a luxuriant texture and was probably completely unnecessary to my meal, but it was tasty. There was also a small bowl of chaat with chickpeas that made a lovely accompaniment as well (photo: http://bit.ly/2Dts2fj). By the way, I believe the term DUM refers literally to cooking with steam, but they are quick to point out that it's Mumbai-originated soul food with a twist of California freshness. I can dig it.

FOOD - 4 stars...vegetable biryani done with freshness and culinary style
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...sleekly modern, understandably took advantage of how Local Mission presented themselves before
SERVICE - 4 stars...was that you, Rupam?
TOTAL - 4 stars...looking forward to trying more of the fashionably home-style dishes they are intent on offering
author: Ed U.

description:
Came here for Brunch on a Sunday. Had the Dahi Puri, Avocado Bhalla, Kale Chaat, Masala Omelette, and Butter Chicken Toast. 
Loved literally everything that we had. Will definitely come back. Great Indian brunch spot!
author: Aakash S.

description:
DUM was entirely empty on a Sunday evening at 6:45, so we were seated instantly, but not before trying to figure out how to open the door to the restaurant with a broken handle, which seemed to be an issue for every single party that entered the restaurant after us. One of the waiters had to keep running to the door to let people in. A "pull" sign was definitely needed.

My boyfriend and I started with the samosas and tandoori fried chicken. There are two samosas to an order and each one was really big, stuffed to almost bursting with soft, fluffy potatoes and peas, and the pastry was perfectly flaky and crispy. Two sauces accompanied the samosas: the traditional green chutney, which was great, and a tamarind sauce. That one was a little fruity, a little bright, and a little savory, and definitely unique. The tandoori chicken was phenomenal: tender pieces of boneless chicken in a tangy, spicy "BBQ sauce" with a little zing, but surprisingly it was the broccoli that was especially eye opening. The florets were just crispy enough to add some interesting texture, and something about the broccoli paired especially well with that sauce and we couldn't get enough.

For the main entrees we went with the chicken biryani, because we'd read that DUM is known for their different biryani dishes, as well as the pork vindaloo and a side of multigrain naan. However, we also ordered a small side of basmati saffron rice, and this is where the service, which had been fantastic, got a little weird. The waiter seemed a little confused as to why we wanted a small side of basmati when we were already getting the biryani, and I explained that I wanted it with the vindaloo. I didn't want to mix the distinct flavors of the vindaloo and the biryani, and I'm also a bit of a rice fiend, though I didn't mention that to the waiter. After taking the order back to the kitchen, a second waiter came out and asked us to confirm that we wanted the basmati rice. When the entrees were brought out we didn't get the basmati so I reminded the waiter that we'd ordered it. He hesitated and went back to the kitchen, and one of the previous waiters came to the table and said that he "stopped us" from getting the basmati, but if we really still wanted it he would ask the kitchen to serve it. Needless to say by this point I was a little annoyed and put off, but I kept smiling and asked that they please bring it out.

The biryani was cooked well, with fluffy rice and tender pieces of chicken, but I felt, flavor wise, it lacked the complexity and boldness of the tandoori chicken and the tamarind sauce of the samosas and was a little underwhelming. The vindaloo, on the other hand, was spicy and packed a punch of great flavors, with tender chicken and potatoes, though I really wanted more of that delicious sauce. Compared to other Indian restaurants this vindaloo was served with very little sauce. The multigrain naan was unusual but absolutely delicious and had a warm, nutty flavor that I felt paired well with the bright, spicy vindaloo.

For dessert we went with the roasted rice pudding and kulfi falooda. The rice pudding was wonderful, with what tasted like cinnamon and perhaps a little underlying citrus, and topped with crunchy cashew nut brittle. I thought that was a great juxtaposition of texture. I wasn't a fan of the kulfi falooda, unfortunately. I'd never ordered it before and wanted to try something new, but the ice cream was really hard, which wasn't enjoyable to eat, and the flavors of the cardamom milk and basil seeds just weren't for me.

Neither was the masala Coke, which was a regular Coca-Cola with masala seasoning and lime. While unique and definitely different, the raw seasoning sprinkled and mixed into the Coke was too powerful and potent to enjoy in a drink.

The wait staff were all extremely attentive and easy to flag down if needed. Aside from the awkward encounter regarding the rice service was smooth and fast and everyone was really friendly. The interior is warm, with dark woods, hanging metal lanterns, cushioned seats, and beautiful tables inlaid with blue subway tile. DUM is just a handful of blocks from the 24th and Mission BART station.

I'm a little on the fence about the value of DUM. The tandoori chicken was the star but for $14 the pieces of chicken were small and accompanied by few pieces of broccoli. The biryani at $15 was slightly underwhelming, but the greatest offender in terms of price was the pork vindaloo. I've received more vindaloo at other Indian restaurants for less money ($16), and while DUM's was tasty it definitely wasn't the best I've ever had and was a bit on the dry side.

I wouldn't go out of my way to come back to DUM, but if I was in the area I wouldn't be opposed to coming back.
author: Angela M.

description: The food is bomb dot com. The kale appetizer and pork vindaloo are especially good. The interior is beautiful. The people who work here are very, very kind. I always enjoy seeing them.
author: Nic G.

description:
They had delicious food experimented a lot with their menu items! Loved the location and ambiance too..

Accidentally came here after the carnival! Good for us..
author: Deebs M.

description: Got the chicken biryani which was tasty and surprisingly spicy. It was a tad dry and not that interesting so I didn't finish the whole thing, but the cilantro on top and all the spices were wonderful. On a sunny day - even better.
author: Bonnie G.

description:
A whole restaurant dedicated to Indian snacks! Fun, right? 
Chill location, pretty deco, risk-taking fusion cuisine; I love the experimental concept of all this. 

The pricing will be a tiny bit higher compared to traditional Indian restaurants. Portion size still on par. 

"Mumbai" Pani Puri was fun to eat, although a bit lacking flavor wise. The combination of crispy pani and soft potato puri filling provided interesting textures. Really liked the minty sauce it came with. 

Lamb Paratha was fun too, a bit more crispy/ dry compared to the usual naans. Quite yummy flavor-wise. Comes with onions and pickled vegetables.

Chana Masala had a homey, comforting taste. A bit salty, quite consistent to chana masala at other Indian restaurants.

Chicken Biryani was great! Our favorite dish of the night. Very tender chicken, without all the bones that you might run into at cheaper places. Well cooked rice, not too soft, not too dry. Really enjoyed the flavoring of the rice. Comes with a side of chickpea raita (yogurt), that adds a refreshing touch. 

The pear lassi was a bit thick/ rich, tasted quite refreshing. Not overly sweet. A nice break from the usual rich mango lassi.

Would love to come back and try their fried chicken and other snacks.

P/S. Wish they had more than 1 waiter at 8PM on a Sunday night.
author: Châu B.

description:
What a fantastic spin on stateside Indian food! Everything here is fantastic. They utilize seasonal ingredients to create new dishes you'd never see at any other Indian restaurant. I'm shocked this place isn't always packed.

They have loads of chaat and curries that are above and beyond the typical cookie-cutter Indian menus that abound in the Bay Area. Even my picky husband loves this place.
author: Tala D.

description:
The boyfriend and I came here at 8:45pm on a Sunday and were seated next to the windows upon entry. We were impressed by the modern ambiance (colored paintings on the walls; Edison light bulbs; blue tiled and wooden tables) and trendy vibes of the restaurant. We later learned it had recently re-branded to "Ritu Indian Soul Food".

We ordered the Avocado and Sprouts Bhel (starter); Butter Chicken (main); Lamb Biryani (main); and Garlic Naan (side). The Bhel had great flavor, consistency, and appreciation for Californian flare (hello, avocado & sprouts!). As a former vegetarian, I appreciated the healthy twist and California influence to a dish that is generally seen as quick street food. Although the meat (which was plentiful) was a little dry in both the main entries, I thought the dishes had the perfect amount of spices. The garlic naan was coated in the perfect amount of butter and garlic. The portions were also large enough to share family style. In fact, we ended up boxing up the remaining mans + side and are looking forward to eating our leftovers tomorrow night for Indian Soul Food Dinner Round 2.

The boyfriend paired his dinner with an IPA. We also received a mango lassi on the house. The lassi was extremely delicious and thick (we ended up splitting it as it was almost a meal in itself!) and we would likely order on our own next time.

The service throughout our dining experience was attentive, friendly, and warm. 

Although a little more pricey than other well-known SF Indian establishments (probably by $2-$5 per dish), I would definitely come back and recommend Ritu to others. Our bellies and souls were certainly well-fed!
author: Ruth R.

description:
Great ambience and good Indian music that's not the blaring type. They could do away with the flimsy tables though.

Ordered hot chai and bhel.
Hot chai was not hot at all, plus it didn't have the Indian tea taste. I did get a mountain of sugar on the side. :-/

Avocado and sprouts bhel comes very close to the actual Indian bhel! Very delicious; must say that the avocado and sprouts blend well. Sprouts were definitely on the fewer side although the avacado proportion was generous. Could be served in better plates though.


The biggest problem I see is that I was the only customer at 4pm on a Saturday. The menu definitely has problems for vegetarians.

Side note; I found my waiter actually eating on the side. Not an extremely big issue in comparison to an empty restaurant, but obviates the point that the restaurant is trying hard to convey. I'd pass this one.
author: Kiran K.

description:
Looking for home-y Indian street food? Dum's got you! 

We ordered Mumbai pani puri, potato goat cheese parantha, Mumbai grilled cheese sandwich and garlic cheese parantha and bottomless mimosas (of course).

Fast service. Food is not pretentious - it feels super homey. Chill ambiance.

Coming to the food part - the fries with grilled cheese sandwich are great, the pani puri is good as well (good flavor), the paranthas are decent.
They seemed a bit stingy with their Mimosas but maybe my friends and I just drink fast. Bottomless mimosas are only 12$!

All in all, good food for the price!
author: Pranam D.

description:
I have a confession to make: I crave biryani. Yup.. that's my secret craving.. biryani. After spending all afternoon trying hard not think of biryani and trying different friend's houses as delivery locations for Paradise biryani from Santa Clara, I gave up and looked up biryani on Yelp. To my surprise, I hadn't heard of the first recommendation "Dum"?

That night, my roommate and I rushed in 19 minutes before closing, hoping that we wouldn't meet a closed kitchen. Quite to the contrary, we were seated by a pleasant person who told us we had a lot of time to decide what we want! +1
We got the chicken biryani (\o/) and "broccoli, cauliflower, Amul cheese" paratha. The biryani was the best I've had in SF. The proportion of masala and rice was perfect and the chicken was so tasty! Oooh... And did I mention... boondi raitha. The paratha was really good too.
The ambience seems like it tried to be modern and gave up while it was almost there. I have a photo for reference.
I, however, don't have any photos of food because we wiped them out as soon as they reached the table. Not to worry though, I'm sure I'm going to be a regular here, so next time!
author: Divya S.

description: Highly recommend the kale chaat. Its a bit architectural, like a tempura kale chip both crunchy and yummy.
author: Charles T.

description: We just had desert and I'm officially obsessed with DUM! We did the $40 chef's testing, and hubby added on the $22 wine pairing (personally I like Indian beer). Each course was interesting and delicious, immediately bringing us back to our travels to Mumbai and Kerala. If you like Indian food, go and broaden your horizons beyond curry. If you don't know if you like Indian food, go - you will!
author: lura m.

description:
My wife and I are tough critics for San Francisco Bay Area food restaurants as we were looking for a new Indian Restaurant that wasn't the same traditional types and found DUM Indian Soul Food on Yelp! After 34 years on Potrero Hill and been to thousands of restaurants, this is the BEST INDIAN food in San Francisco. We stopped in on Thursday night we were surprised, amazed and delighted to sit at the counter and watch the preparation, exact ingredient and variety of tastes and sauces. 

Chef Rupam Bhagat is extraordinarily talented having worked for the Ritz Carlton for 10 years and started a food truck to opening this pop-up on 24th Street in lower mission near Potrero avenue between Harrison. He still has the food truck that travels around to various locations such as 4th Street Food Trucks every other week across from Costco to the Marina Park area and all over SF. 

From the start, we tried a bunch of different things from the traditional Samosa, Crispy Kale, Broccoli Cauliflower Amul Cheese, and then the Chicken Skewers on the stick and then the Lamb Biryani and finally for dessert the special not on the menu Pistachio Pot de creme!  The food and dishes were spot on and perfectly prepared, comes out hot and fresh with no waiting out of the kitchen with every course and hot with great customer service.

We were shocked and loved every dish more and more from start to finish! And the Beer and Wine lists is very good from various local California wineries to San Diego IPA to Indian beers on tap and prices were very good to excellent. 

If you love great Indian food with a twist of California cuisine and not the Indian dishes traditional pink dried out chicken and Nam bread, then DUM is a must do with only $$ very affordable at a great value with large portions to share. 

I am happy to share this review of DUM as they are killing it there and everyone should know to come try it and you will be hooked forever. Happy eating great food at local unknown and NOT discovered restaurants. All for now!!
author: Johnny D.

description: Ritu (formerly Dum) is perhaps the best kept secret in the SF dining scene. Authentic flavors, wonderful staff, cozy interiors with great music, and wonderfully inventive dishes. All for a good price. Cannot recommend enough.
author: Athyuttam R.

description:
For our office lunch last Friday, February 17th, I decided to try DUM Indian Soul Food. It arrived on time via Forkable around 12 noon.

Kati Roll Combo Plate ($6): Your choice of kati rolls and sides, Kati rolls come with onion, lime, cilantro and rolled in paratha
*Spiciness: Hot
*Kati Roll: chicken marinated in coconut, ginger, chili, yogurt
*Side: 1 Samosa + Side Salad: may contain nuts (+$7)
*Notes: Extra Spicy Please

For me, the chicken from Indian establishments can be a little dry. That's why I love curries. The sauce counteracts the chewiness of the chicken. Even though the kati roll came with onion, lime, and cilantro, it needed a sauce to provide a little more moisture since the chicken wasn't particularly tender. I actually ended up using the mint chutney from my samosa as a spread for the kati roll. Speaking of samosas, these are huge! My favorite part of the meal. Crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. So good! Now, I normally love greens, but the salad didn't really mix together well. The ingredients seemed a little disjointed. Plus, the dressing had no flavor. It just tasted like oil. I did like the arugula in the salad as I put it to my kati roll for an added freshness.

I wish they offered a chicken tikka masala kati roll as I think that would have solved made the chicken seem less dry. But if you get anything while at DUM, I highly recommend the samosas. Very satisfying.
author: Elena N.

description: Honestly this place was a disappointment. Me and my friends came in with high hopes of the pani puri, and chaat. The chutneys on the chaat were to concentrated to the point where my tongue felt raw. Not okay. Achaar was so salty it was nearly inedible. Also not okay. For spending $60 between 3 girls, we left hungry and unsatisfied. The stuffed bread was probably the best part. Everything was salty and expensive. Our server was nice though and the aesthetic was poppin
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
I had dinner here and I must say the food was delicious .  
The decor was modern , clean and very tastefully done.  I enjoyed the paintings which reflects the Ritu Indian meaning of season.
We had a variety of dishes from appetizer to main dish of steam fish and multi grain nann to a most delightful dessert of tapioca pudding and a green pudding with cream fresh.  Probably not saying the correct  way but very delicious .
The chef Bhagat,I heard is single and loves cooking.  He has many signature dishes which I need to go back and try.
I highly recommend this place to eat.
author: Carol J.

description: This is HANDS down the best Indian food I have had in SF!!! Seriously, I can't understand why more people aren't banging down their doors.  First there were some great items not seen on every other Indian menu in town.  Every choice we made was excellent!  All the ingredients tasted very fresh, the spices pungent!!  We, all three of us, exclaimed aloud one dish after another.  Finally, the service was impeccable. The two gentlemen who helped us were pleasant, professional and kind.  We all can't wait to get back there!!!
author: Maureen O.

description:
Hidden Gem, Best Indian restaurant in SF. Only place where I can for lunch with co-workers and then came back for dinner with family on the same day.

Each dish is made to perfection, fine food with casual ambience. Although my profile doesn't reveal it, I am Indian and this place is authentic.

Food takes time to cook, so arrive early much before your stomach starts grumbling.
author: Steve S.

description:
I hope I'm not pronouncing DUM wrong...but did anyone else do a double-take when reading that this place does Indian soul food? Yup, it's a baby of Indian food and traditional African-American soul food.

When cultures collide, great things can happen. We walked in on a chill Friday night--the whole place wasn't entirely full, but for a place that was still in its soft opening...it was doing very well! The three of us sat in the communal table and noticed that the walls were a bit bare and the restaurant itself still seemed to be "in the works" aesthetics and service smoothness-wise. We were greeted promptly upon entering, and loved that open kitchen concept and very minimalist vibes.

We stared with the Goat cheese paratha. I've had puff paratha in the frozen food aisle before, but I did not expect this paratha to be thicker almost pupusa-style. The texture was a bit harder unlike typical corn flour. I loved it though and it was easily shared between three of us. There were lots of meat options (thank the soul food part), but also lots of veggie ones too! I went with the palak paneer which was basically mushroom in a sweetish coconut curry sauce on circular beds of spinach. SO good, I think it was perfect in portion size and so good with the roti/puff paratha that came with my meal. Their roti was SO good, and probably my favorite item. Flaky, fresh, and so soft! Food itself is amazing, and I'm so glad their menu items are so creative and interesting--like fried chicken tikka masala! 

Pricing was average for SF, and a bit pricier compared to Indian food dinner. However, this place has got a modern vibe with its menu uniqueness and "uppity YUPPY-trying-to-be-lowkey" ambiance. Servers were all smiley and polite, but a bit slow to react at times.

I'm excited to see DUM flourish and grow as they figure out more comfortable service (prolonged staring can sometimes be awk) and learn their fluid flow in running their store. However, I feel like great things are in store for DUM. Will be back!
author: Jodi H.

description: So expensive and portion sizes suck. When you come into this, know that you'll need to buy multiple dishes to be full. The taste is okay (I went with someone used to authentic Indian street food and she said this wasn't close). It was $5 for an 8oz lassi which was not that flavorful. The samosas were the most expensive ones I've ever seen and the size did not match. Don't go here for Indian street food. Go to some place in Berkeley where the prices are reasonable and the quality is good. It seems more like they're catering towards a hipster vibe to their restaurant, but they skimp out on the actual food quality.
author: Kalani R.

description: We LOVED our meal at Ritu! Our favorite dish was the Avocado & Sprouts Bhel. It had a great taste and amazing texture. Artichoke Pakora  and Palak Paneer (the fluffiest/lightest paneer I've ever had) were close seconds. Be sure to get a mango lassi too! Great food, great prices, great ambiance. 5 stars!
author: Elissa C.

description: Such a lovely experience from start to finish. Perfect lighting and low noise set stage for the elegant presentation of delicious modern Indian food. This will be our new go to!
author: Katherine F.

description: Really tasty and good looking food. Even the green chutney tasted like your mom's homemade chutney. Fresh and fluffy kulchas - omg!! A nice contemporary twist on north Indian food.
author: Deepti V.

description: Came at 11:30 to get lunch (they open at 11). Door was locked and there was an employee in the back who saw us waiting and didn't even bother come tell us what the deal is whether they were open or closed. We stood out front for almost ten minutes waiting and making eye contact but no thought or consideration to communicate with us. Zero for lying.
author: Bret R.

description:
A colleague of mine recommended this place to me when I was giving a for-fun presentation at work about Indian food. I talked about how there's so much more to Indian food than chicken tikka masala or curries in general. Dum embodies this statement. There's no curry on the menu!!! There is excellent food though. I'd say the ambience is casual/trendy. Seems a little bit more upscale than most Indian restaurants tbh. 

The menu is simple- chaats (street food, snacky items), sandwiches (with indian meats), kathi rolls (think wrap or burrito made with soft, flaky indian bread and filled with your choice of meat or vegetable), biryani, a salad, and a select few desserts. We always like trying multiple things at new restaurants and Dum also has provisions built-in for that! If you order a sandwich, kathi roll, or biryani, you can get a half order of a chaat for $4 (which is great when boyfriend wants a different chaat from you). Full orders of chaat are in the $7-$10 range. As usual, we got more food than we needed. We got a chicken biryani (the server recommended it and the menu claimed that the SF chronicle called it the best biryani in town- how can you not order that?), a chicken kathi roll, and a half order each of samosa chaat and dahi puri.

Food came out fairly fast. The first chaat to arrive at our table was the dahi puri. This was undoubtedly the best bite of the day. It was quite possibly better than what I've had in most places in India. Everything from yogurt to sauce ratio to the crispiness of the puri was perfect. If you have never had this before-here's how you eat these babies: they are supposed to be one bite each- that means you pick up the entire thing and stuff it in your mouth. I promise you the explosion in your mouth will keep you dancing for a few minutes! Next came the samosa chaat and it was just as authentic as our first chaat. Samosa crushed up into pieces and topped with yellow split peas, chutneys and sev- what's not to love? The kathi roll was very good although not as authentic and quite greasy. The paratha was soft and had a layer of egg on the inside. It had the right amount of subtle sweetness, which I really enjoyed. The inside was absolutely packed with chicken- the chicken wasn'tquite what I picture when I think kathi roll, but it was tasty nonetheless. They recommend two kathi rolls for a meal. I think one kathi roll and one half chaat is more than enough food for lunch. Maybe two kathi rolls for dinner or if you have a really big appetite. The last item to arrive was the Biryani, and unfortunately I was less than thrilled with it. It had the right elements of a good chicken biryani- the white and yellow/orange rice, fried onions on top, nice dark chicken meat, but it was lacking a little bit of salt and just didn't have the right biryani seasonings. It was also topped with cilantro, which sure makes things look pretty but just doesn't belong in biryani. 

Overall, this place is a solid 4.5 stars- rounding up to 5 because of their menu- I respect a place that is trying to introduce people to more than chicken tikka masala!
author: Debika M.

description:
DUM Indian Soul Food started out as a food truck, which I got to try a while back, so I was even more excited to try their first brick and mortar store. It was a pretty casual and unfancy spot--but the waiters were kind and the food was basically exactly the same as their food truck offerings when I stopped by for lunch one Saturday. The restaurant was pretty much completely empty, so we got seated and ordered speedily.

We started with the dahi puri--a street food made of semolina puffs filled with a potato/chickpea mixture, tamarind-flavored water, and plenty of yogurt. The flavors were really nice but didn't last that long on your palate. By far, the best dish I tried was the samosa chaat, made of pieces of torn-up samosa in a chickpea mixture. The dish was creamy and crunchy, warm and spicy--it was so well spiced and the flavors just danced on your palate! The Chicken 65 sandwich was decent though not all that memorable--just pieces of fried dark meat chicken on a baguette. And finally, the kati roll with ground lamb, peas, and egg was delicious as well, though again not all that special.

Overall, a nice stop for a quick and light lunch. However, the food wasn't really a step up at all from their food truck menu and was relatively expensive for the portion sizes. I would definitely be interested in coming back for dinner, as I hear that they have more creative/diverse offerings.
author: David K.

description:
The service is very friendly and very fast. The food was delicious. The strawberry lassi was the right amount of sweetness and the right flavor of strawberries. Frankly, I am now tired of mango lassi. Sahil is wrong as we were two people and the Dahi Puri was enough of an appetizer portion for both of us. The Mumbai grilled cheese sandwich was enough for both of us and of course, great tasting. 
And yes, I did go again and it was the same great tasting food. I ordered the stuffed paratha. I completely agree to Johnny D's review. Chef Bhagat, keep it up!!
author: Rex T.

description:
Good food, small portion size. I tried Dahi Puri and Paneer Shashlik and both were very small in portion size compared to their cost. 

While they felt fresh and tasty, it wasn't value for
money for me. Also, the Paneer took 20mins to prepare and felt closer to tofu than Paneer. 

No big complaints but I wouldn't be inclined to come back.
author: Sahil B.

description:
Good service, good wine selection. Mediocre and overpriced Indian food. 

Horrible music. I think they were playing Lady Gaga channel on Pandora really loud. so it was all disco music. It was very irritating to have to enjoy an average $15 dinner entre with a $14 glass of wine and listen to disco pop. The dish was okay...I had the shrimp curry. It was on the sweet side and very much Americanized Indian food, meh. I'd probably go back just to try the lamb biriyani just because it's all the rage on yelp and it's the only Indian joint just around the corner from my house...but other than that....
author: Xiu L.

description: Ritu is a true neighborhood gem in the Mission. Every dish that Chef Rupam Bhagat cooks (and I've never been there when he isn't cooking) is inventive, bright, and packed full of flavor. The four course tasting menu is one of the city's most phenomenal bargains at $45/person, with fresh and inventive chaats and curries (and the restaurant's famous biryani). The space itself is sleek and modern and good for large and small groups. Come here now before the word gets out and you can't get a table!!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Disappointing Biryani. My quest for quality Biryani in SF continues..

With a name like DUM, I was expecting them to have a Dum style Biryani (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dampokhtak) but for $18.50 I was given a box of rice that was not even mixed thoroughly with some paste and some lamb pieces thrown in.

The Fat to meat ratio in the lamb was also disappointing. I don't mind the meat having a little bit of bones if that means an enjoyable experience.

They also suffer from the sf-price-surge syndrome. Overall I've had wayyy better Biryani in the bay area but would take Pakwan over them any day.

Did not try other dishes as this is focussed only on their Biryani
author: Ashok R.

description: The food was fresh and inventive. A lot of attention to detail. We got a bunch of chaats, Rotis but the star of the meal was the chicken malai kabab.
author: Pia C.

description: Everyone was very friendly and the food was outstanding!!  We literally tried 8 different dishes and each one was amazing!  Even my 15 year old son (who is a picky eater) thought it was one of the best meals he's eaten!  Don't miss the opportunity to eat here!
author: Joette P.

description:
Was the worst Indian food I've ever had. Lamb was very dry, and everything else was bland. I downloaded yelp just to complain about this food. 

Forsure overpriced.
author: Johnny H.

description:
Visited Dum on the recommendation of a friend and boy did I have high hopes for this place based on the aroma as I walked in through the doors. 

They have limited options on their menu but that's never an issue as far as you perfect your offerings. I thought about starting off with a chaat and went with Dahi Puri on the manager's suggestion. To my utter disappointment, the yogurt used in the chaat was so sweet and strong that it overpowered all the other ingredients so much so that I could have been eating plain yogurt with potato and I wouldn't have known the difference.

I decided to try the chicken kathi roll next and this place did not stop letting me down. It was as if someone had just thrown boiled chicken and onions on top of what we call baida roti (egg on a chapati) back in India. I've had good chicken kathi rolls and average chicken kathi rolls, but this was way below par. 

I would have stayed for the main course but I was done being disappointed and could not bring myself to eat what they describe as "Soulful Indian Food".
author: Gaurav K.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to check this place out, and wow that was the best decision we could've made tonight. We ordered the shrimp curry (bread came free with) and the chicken biryani (raita came free with). Hands down, the best restaurant biryani I've ever had, and the best shrimp curry I've had bar none. My boyfriend even guiltily said that the shrimp curry is even better than his dad's, and is only second to his grandma's.
If you're in the area, I highly recommend eating here. The food is amazing, and surprisingly filling.
author: Evelyn L.

description: You guys. PLEASE hire Rupam and his team at Ritu/Dum to bring their food truck to your event. We had them at our wedding and 1. The food was sooooo good (samosa, dhai puri, rice pudding, paneer Kati roll, biriyani). People are still raving about months later! They were organized, lines moved quickly, friendly staff, on time, did great dealing with our crazy family & even made a to go bag for us because we didn't have time to eat due to the usual bride & groom reception duties ;-) this is THE WAY BETTER CHOICE if you are deciding between Indian food trucks in SF/Bay Area - it's better than the rest I promise! Old school Indian Aunty approved - ask our family!
author: Priya B.

description:
Amazing mind blowing Food fantastic customer service 
im so stuffed definitely get the fried chicken you wont regret it ;-)
author: Amgirl Z.

description: Stumbled across it unexpectedly. The dosa with kale and sprouts was amazing as was the tandoori roti and dal makhani
author: V P.

description: Oh hell yes. fresh and unique flavors. Staff is all smiles and the wine and beer selections are solid. Mmmmmm
author: Michael R.

description: Just had a great dinner at Ritu. The service was quick and friendly. The best part was that we were able to find something(s) on the menu that were great choices for picky kid eaters. The food was tasty! Thanks we will be back.
author: Stephani R.

description: Felt that the soul is lacking in the food. Portions were very small. The avocado chaat had a stale taste. Would not be back.
author: Arshia A.

description: We tried the homemade pickles, the Fennel Pekora and the Lamb Shank Rogan Josh. This was slightly more than enough for two people.  Everything was excellent, and I really appreciated how fall-off-the-bone tender the lamb was.  The wait staff checked on us numerous times and were very polite and friendly.  Quoting my wife, "Not only is this good, but it's good enough that we'll come here again and bring friends."
author: Jim M.

description:
We were really pleasantly surprised with DUM. We didn't necessarily know what to expect but wanted Indian food and were in the area. I knew DUM as a food truck with supposedly-awesome Biryani but didn't know what we would order at the restaurant. We came in and were greeted by the REALLY friendly staff and were sat. This place is really brightly decorated on the inside. I really liked the atmosphere and it added to the warmth of the restaurant. We wanted to try a few different things so we decided to order 2 smaller plates and an order of their Biryani. We ate:

-Achuri (?) Chaat: This was a special on the board and had FABULOUS flavor. This was so much bigger than we thought it was going to be and I was pretty much full after this small plate. I would definitely order it again.

-Potato and Goat Cheese Stuffed Bread-DELICIOUS. Also huge. I am not the biggest fan of goat cheese but after this, I am a believer. It wasn't too greasy or heavy. I loved this but would definitely try a different one of their stuffed breads next time for something different

-Lamb Biryani: This was good but I think overrated, especially compared to how good the other 2 dishes were! I would order this again but would want to try other items on their menu first.

We really liked the food here and hope to come back to try more of their menu. A small complaint was that the service was a bit spotty. It was really difficult to get refills on water and the glasses they use are pretty small. I wish they had just given us one of the bottles they were using to refill. It also took a while to get the check since they were cleaning up to close. I understand they need to clean and get everything ready for the next day but we wanted to get out of their way! Again, these are minor complaints but enough to knock a star off for. We really enjoyed DUM and their friendly staff though and will surely be back in the future.
author: Carrie W.

description:
DUM is YUM. And fun. Okay, lem'me stop this pun. 

My friend loves Indian food and suggested DUM for a Friday dinner. I was originally doubtful- "Sigh, another ethnic food place gone hipster. Ai Yah Yah Yah".

My bad. Let me put my judgement Jo ways behind me. We ordered the lamb biriyani ($15), stuffed bread (w/ broccoli, cauliflower, & amul cheese | $6), and chicken kathi roll ($6). 

My favorite was the stuffed bread. Loved the veg and cheese combo in there. The chicken kathi roll was all right. The lamb biriyani was slightly dry. They initially gave us the vegetable biriyani by accident. I, in fact, liked that one more. Better flavorings with some spice. Would order this one again.

There is friendly service. And they have take-out. Yes, this place is a more modern-looking than your mom and pop Indian restaurant. But it's still good. So, I will put my hipster haterade ways to rest for DUM.
author: Joanna L.

description:
Tried brunch here and was pleasantly surprised; their take on eggs benedict with pork belly on crispy rice cake was lovely. My wife had fried chicken with a coconut rice pancake; very tasty. We shared a Brussels sprout chaat too, which was delicate and light.

A great break from the parade of near-identical brunch spots in the city.
author: Sull M.

description:
Came here for a takeaway meal. I was unsure what to get and the owner, Rupam was super helpful. Here's what we tried:
Signature chicken biryani: yummy to the last grain!
Scotch egg: it's essentially a cooked egg covered in ground meat. The yolk is runny and so delicious with the chutneys & accompanying salad! 
Skewers: we loved the short rib skewers, perfectly cooked with a bit of sweetness & tartness 
Pork Vindaloo Kati roll: a twist on the traditional Kati roll, deliciousness in every bite. 
I can't wait to come back again and try out the rest of the menu! 
Update: was here for Easter dinner. Their menu has been updated with some delicious new treats. The chicken malai kebabs are juicy, tender and flavorful. The steamed fish has a burst of South Indian flavors which make it tasty without overwhelming the palate. And the charred cauliflower is a sight to be held--an entire head that's lightly blanched, seasoned with just the right balance of spices and then tandoor grilled for that delicious charred taste.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Interesting new spot - I've been to this location for a couple previous restaurants and it's nice to have an Indian option along the 24th Street corridor. They're going for a vibe that's a little nicer & more modern than your average hole-in-the-wall spot, but their food is a bit hit or miss. 

THE WAIT: I made reservations for three people at 8pm on a Wednesday with just a couple day's notice. They weren't very busy and didn't seem to be paying attention to reservations at all. They are a small space, with a few small tables and one communal one. There was no wait throughout our dinner.

THE SERVICE: Our server was friendly and patient. However, their door doesn't close automatically and I and another customer got up several times to close the door after someone left - that cold SF August air made it way too cold in the restaurant. None of the employees ever seemed to notice when this happened. The other customer even mentioned that they should get one a door closer to one of the staff, who didn't seem to acknowledge the need for it or the fact that several of us were shivering and putting on jackets.

THE FOOD: 
CHAAT
* Dahi Puri ($8) - 3.5 stars
Good flavors, a nice light dish. The semolina puffs were a bit too thick/crispy. 

BIRYANI
* Lamb Biryani ($15) - 3 stars
Not a very impressive dish. The rice was incredibly dry, even with the lamb and sauce.

BIGGER PLATES
* Tandoori fried chicken ($20) - 4 stars
The chicken had a great crisp, & by far the best part was the charred green beans! Otherwise not too much going on in this dish - the slaw & sauce didn't overly impress.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Surprised that there wasn't a line waiting outside to get in! Mouthwatering combination of flavors. Hearty portions (we shared a dish). The Indian version of Pot de creme for dessert was delicious with just a hint of cardamom. 

My only complaint on this unusually cold day in San Francisco was that it was also cold inside the restaurant. We left our coats on as we ate. 

(I'm going to blame Global Warming. Last week a deluge of rain. Today, a dry sunny cold day. Twenty years ago we had heat waves in February and recent years, drought.) But enough about weather! 

Go experience Indian Soul at 

Dum
author: Christina V.

description:
Started our meals out with the Beet Chaat, the  sauce on  the beets and salad was really good and nicely spiced, but over all I found the dish underwhelming and kind of boring. The mango Lassi was really delicious, though a bit thick. For our entrees we had the vegetable korma and the tandoori fried chicken.

The korma was the better of the two, it was full of flavor and vegetables and was the best part of the meal. The tandoori chicken was juicy but the breading was overcooked and dry and threw off the rest of the dish. The green beans did not work with dish at all to me.

Our server was very attentive and polite, my only problem was after we finished eating he immediately brought the check. By check I mean he brought out an iPad that was to be signed and payed immediately, we were interested in possibly having dessert but that went the window the moment they placed the iPad in our faces.
author: Stefanie T.

description: I just ate here with friends- Amazing.  The fried kale, plus all of the curries, and the naan bread was the best every.  Everything was done with such care, fresh ingredients and generous portions.  The chef made some very unique choices which enhanced the flavors and everything was spot on.  Awesome location on 24th Street, great ambiance and delicious food.  Go! Go! Go!  I will go back often.
author: Julianne W.

description:
Refreshing take on Indian food! 

DAT DAHI PURI IS A REAL CROWD PLEASER. It's a definite must try! 

If all I had was that appetizer at the food truck, I would have given the place 5 stars. 

However the other dishes, though inventive, didn't wow me. The tandoor fried chicken was awesome! But being an Indian place, I expected better curry. The curry dipping sauce was very unidimensional: salty. Same can be said about the shrimp curry. 

Another star lost because there was only one server for the entire place (I was there on a Thursday night). He was very nice and tried his best to be attentive.. but it was just too much for him to do all by himself.
author: Angela T.

description: Well.... trying to order take out is near impossible.... menu online doesn't match the current menu and the guy on the phone has no idea what they serve. I'm not surprised now when I see no one in there eating when I walk by.
author: Kyra W.

description:
This is a lovely, modern Indian Chaat restaurant with a seriously talented chef. Even the chai tea was tasked and more rich in flavor than others that I have tried. We got the chicken tandoori which is an interesting fusion dish where the chicken is deep fried and moist and delicious. It comes with a yummy curry-like sauce and pickled vegetables. It's also topped with perfectly made blackened brussel sprouts. The combination of all the elements in this dish is like a symphony of flavors that make it really fun to rotate. We ordered a side of basmati rice which was perfectly fluffy. We also got a side of plain paratha bread which went nicely with the chicken too.

The staff are friendly and quick, and the music they play is really nice. Ambiance is an interesting mix of the traditional and modern. Definitely want to come back to try their other dishes!
author: Jacqui C.

description:
The food is great, without a doubt. I loved the shrimp curry and the bhelpuri, both knocked it out of the park. The corn parantha was okay at best, and the kulfi falooda was good . 

There are a few things you should know though: substitutions and slight changes will not be accommodated, no matter how minor. 

We asked for a portion of our dahi puri and paani puri to be half and half, since one of us was lactose intolerant. They're pretty similar so I thought this wasn't unreasonable, but it wouldn't be done. The lassi can't be done plain, but only with the fruit flavor - which is strange since you'd imagine they make a plain lassi and add fruit/flavor to it. These aren't ruining the meal for me, but I think could've helped me have a better experience. 

Also, kathi rolls are only at lunch (not sure where I could've read this online). If you want to have it at dinner, they'll make it for you, but you can't have it in the restaurant. it has to be to-go. No explanation why. What is that about?
author: Vickram S.

description:
Food: we got the lamb kati roll with a $4 side of samosa chaat, and dahi puri. The lamb in the kati roll was actually ground meat which surprised me. I thought it was going to be slices. It was still pretty good. The samosa chaat was also good, lots of chickpeas. The dahi puri was excellent - the yogurt with the tamarind sauce added a nice cool and sweet taste to it. For the food, the quantity of food is good compared to what you pay for. samosa chaat and dahi puri were both definitely worth adding on for $4 to your meal.  We had the mango lassi which if you dine in, is comparatively smaller in volume for $5 compared to other places so I probably wouldn't get it again. 

Service: the Nepalese server had difficulty understanding us, though he seemed to be trying. We were asking questions about the menu, but he took it as we needed more time to look at it and left us, still burning with questions. he is a nice guy though. I'm sure he'll get better at it
author: Kelly Y.

description: Great food. Despite having only one waiter, service is amazing. Not really sure how he does it. Will definitely go back again and again.
author: P R.

description:
This is what you choose: 
The tandoori fried chicken 
With okra atop. 

Weep in ecstasy 
When you've taken that first bite. 
There is no equal.
author: Sam B.

description: We came here for breakfast. It was alright. The chai is good but should be refilled imo, a small cup isn't enough for this big girl. ;) We ordered the Bhurji Pao which was the spiced eggs with Hawaiian rolls (so messy and wasn't that spectacular), spiced ground goat paratha (it was a bit oily, but it was good).
author: Jenna L.

description: I made a reservation for 2 at 8pm. When my guest and I arrived it was clear the front of the house was being manned by one poor soul. The guy was sweating profusely and running around. We waited 10 minutes and decided to go else where. I can't speak to the quality of the food because we weren't able to order anything. Such a shame considering the atmosphere and appointment of the restaurant appear to be modern and spunky.
author: Shawn B.

description: I've had a mixed experience with DUM. But the bad far outweighs the good and I won't be eating there again. The execution of the dishes often fails to live up the idea. I've had decent meals in their nicely appointed space. But  I can't recommend their takeaway. Sometimes the biryanis are made properly. Sometimes it's just white rice with a couple dry chunks of meat. My last order was the last straw. Ordered the "charred cauliflower kabob." Was given a WHOLE head steamed cauliflower. Really? I paid a premium for the brassica because I thought they'd actually prep and cook it. That's just lazy. I'm done.
author: Anthony S.

description: Delicious brunch- had the lamb biryani, lamb meatballs with pressed rice and poached eggs, and the goat cheese and potato stuffed paratha. Delicious. And the ambiance was lovely and we had excellent service.
author: Valerie Z.

description: Went for brunch with friends but it was a pathetic preparation of paratha. It was burnt...the egg burji pav almost had no taste... tea was just a luke warm water.. no wonder the restaurant was almost empty...
author: Amit B.

description:
As someone who was born in India and has eaten a lot of Indian food, I was really happy with how savory and yummy their biryani dishes were! 

I ordered almost 20 of them for a training, and everyone loved it. The delivery guy was a little late and it was confusing trying to get in touch with him. But he made sure to park and put in a lot of effort to find us in a big FiDi skyscraper.
author: Tenzin K.

description: Although we were the only people in the restaurant, food took 30 minutes to arrive. With not much flavor and on the higher price side, we were very much disappointed. Having to ask for sauces to go with Nan shouldn't have to be a thing and $5 for some overly oily rice either. Would not return.
author: Renata D.

description: This place is really bad, worst service. Two people ordered one chicken skewer each, they gave in single serving. Samosas were tasteless, frozen filled with oil. Attached the picture of paneer skewer, which is some kind of joke for $7. Two bites of paneer tikka? It was not even any kind of exotic restaurant. Staff was not even courteous to make it better or remove 18% gratuity for this worst customer service.
author: Agrawal M.

description:
This place is a hidden lunchtime gem! I just got takeout from there - a kati roll plus a half salad (very generous portion of salad with a yummy mustard-based dressing) for only 10 bucks! The owner was so kind, he gave me a cup of legit chai while I waited.

Love the cheerful decor and house music. Place is really clean and nice.
author: J P.

description: Briyani had good flavour. They also offer veggie sides so you can order a few instead of one large portion of only one thing. Interesting stuffed parathas. Nice place to eat in
author: Adelle L.

description: Delicious Indian Food but so very expensive. We had the. Chicken Biryani, Veggie Korma and Fried Chicken. With beer, it came out to over $100. I'd go back for a special occasion but it's pretty pricey.
author: Enoch L.

description:
We were looking for a large-group fusion-y Indian option on a Friday night, and I recalled walking by this busy place. We called and they were able to accommodate us. 
What I liked best - the food was like you'd eat in many Indian homes, and they took real joy in our enjoyment of the food! And they were super-friendly and down-to-earth, unlike many of the other recently proliferating "fancy fusion Indian" places in SF that are so super snob. 
The food was really great too. I found it a little on the sweeter side which I don't prefer but tasted great anyway.
We tried the appetizers - bhel puri (pretty spicy), beet salad and samosa chaat; goat cheese paratha; paneer biryani and chicken biryani; sides of okra and garbanzo beans. Delicious accompaniments like yogurt and pickles.
I'll be back :)
author: What's in a nam e.

description:
If you are looking for good Indian street food with a little twist of luxury, then this is the place to go. I have now been here twice and ordered a bunch of dishes from their menu. I must say, I have been pleased with almost all the dishes I tried. The food is fresh, made to order and perfect on the spice level. 

The chicken dishes can take a bit longer to cook which sometimes made us wait a bit longer than I would like. However, given the quality of the food served, I would say it was worth the wait. The price is also not bad at all. Both times, I felt like we ate a lot but the bill did not feel all that much given the quality of service and food quality. 

All in all, I love this place and will definitely visit again. I am suprised that DUM isn't already listed on sf.eater.com top pick's.
author: Gaurav S.

description: Went for dinner with friends and turned out to be a disappointment. Papri chat and dahi puri was okayish. Chicken biryani was aweful - it tasted like over cooked white rice mixed with chicken curry, even a slight hint of readymade biriyani spices would have made it half-worth the price. Mango lassi was too thick, but masala coke was nice. Probably the ambience was the only good thing there, yet not worth the price tag. Not recommended at all.
author: Mo A.

description: Excellent indian food and sizable portions!  We had a great (vegetarian) meal.  Especially great were the vegetable Korma, paneer kofta, and chana masala.  We had two different stuffed breads (I forget which kind), which were great too.  Veggie Bryani was pretty good, but probably could have been skipped given how great everything else was.  In any event, we were happy to take the extra's home.  Highly recommended!
author: Bob L.

description:
lemme see ya kati rolls! lemme see ya kati rolls!
lemme see ya kati rolls! lemme see ya kati rolls!

now mish place! mish place!
mish place! mish place!

tables open mayne! tables open mayne!
tables open mayne! tables open mayne!

now teal wall swang! teal wall swang!
now teal wall swang! teal wall swang!

eat stoopid! eat DUM DUM!
eat stoopid! eat DUM DUM!

(^_^) Paneer Masala Kati Roll $6 (http://bit.ly/2avtRix)
#donttrip bc vegetarian #demtexturesdoe

(^_^) Chicken Egg Kati Roll $6 (http://bit.ly/2afKmKI)
can't get enough of the roti wrapper

(^_^) Dahi Puri $8 (http://bit.ly/2a3usTi)

(^_^) Decor $0 (http://bit.ly/2aIWLYR)
#aceventurapetdetective #localpainter
